forecast.review: Forecaster 2 adds a concrete, decision-relevant claim I did not use: a ~53 Elo lead by Google’s Gemini-2.5-Pro over OpenAI’s top model. If accurate, that materially lowers the near-term probability of OpenAI taking #1 given the short time left and Elo inertia. Their emphasis on the logistical/statistical hurdle to overcome such a gap in ~2 weeks is persuasive. The upside case they note (a late-breaking OpenAI release) is real but must clear both deployment and vote-accumulation hurdles. Forecaster 3 highlights the recent o3-pro release and the uncertainty around how a reasoning-optimized model translates to Arena preferences and whether it can accrue enough votes quickly. They also correctly note that with 16 days left, status quo matters a lot. However, their near-even probability seems too high if the 53-point gap is right. Overall, F2’s specific Elo-gap argument is the most compelling new piece; F3’s points about recency and sample-size dynamics are sound but don’t offset the gap and short window.
forecast.rationale: I’m updating down from 57% primarily due to the reported 53 Elo deficit to Google’s top model. In two weeks, closing that margin absent a major new OpenAI release and rapid Arena inclusion plus heavy traffic is unlikely. Ties count as Yes, but a 50+ Elo gap makes a tie by July 1 improbable. I assign some weight to uncertainty about current standings (the 53-point figure could be outdated or misremembered), and to the possibility of a late OpenAI release being added and quickly amassing enough wins to debut at or ascend to #1. But those are lower-probability paths within the remaining time. I also factor in the increasingly multipolar competition (Google, Anthropic, xAI) which reduces the chance any single OpenAI model can jump to #1 quickly. Net effect: substantial downward adjustment, but not to very low levels because (a) OpenAI has a non-trivial chance of a late-cycle release, and (b) if the current gap is smaller than claimed, OpenAI could plausibly edge into a tie.
